H0.text: Development of chemical rocks is the part of the rock cycle most likely associated with areas of convergence, in addition to the formation of mountains, as studied by scientists.

H1.text: Development of extrusive rocks is the part of the rock cycle most likely associated with convergent boundaries studied by scientists, besides the occurrence of mountains.

H2.text: The development of layered rocks is the other part of the rock cycle most likely associated with convergent boundaries, where scientists have studied collisions that produce mountains.

H3.text: The development of folded rocks is the part of the rock cycle most likely associated with convergent boundaries, where scientists study the collisions that also produce mountains.

A4.text: Folds can also be formed as a result of displacement on a non-planar fault (fault bend fold), at the tip of a propagating fault (fault propagation fold), by differential compaction or due to the effects of a high-level igneous intrusion e.g. above a laccolith.

A5.text: When plates collide or undergo subduction (that is, ride one over another), the plates tend to buckle and fold, forming mountains.

A6.text: While volcanic arcs form at oceanic-continental plate boundaries, folding occurs at continental-continental plate boundaries.
